regretList.regret: My most significant regret is not taking bigger risks when I was younger. I had a tendency to accept things the way they were or cling to mediocre but comfortable choices. Having been raised poor, it took me a long time to make changes to my life when I was in my 20s and early 30s. I stayed in jobs and relationships too long. I didn't move away out of state. I didn't study abroad. I didn't travel out of the country until I was 36! I wish I could go back and shake my younger self and say: Okay, so you have a job, now, which is better than NOT having a job. But you don't need to settle for that. Keep looking. Keep making choices that the fun you're having, the money you're making, and your general excitement at being alive. Don't cling so much to what you have because it's limiting what you can be and achieve.
Spending most of my life focusing on others instead of what makes me happy
Not starting a self-directed retirement plan in my 30s.
Not giving my time and money to help those in need
Having an abortion. Having to say I’m so sorry when I meet him/her in Heaven. Sigh...

I regret placing my family and work obligations in front of building and maintaining lasting friendships.  I also regret any time I didn’t stick to my core values, those decisions usually had unfortunate consequences.
My biggest regret is living by the rules and not having as much fun in my life.
Not listening to that little inner voice that was screaming at me to keep my mouth shut. I have often ignored it and deeply regretted it every single time.
Failed to stop and help a young woman in her car with a baby on a bridge in Manhattan
Not being more assertive
Marrying the wrong person at 26
I regret that none of my teachers helped me to discover my passions early on. It didn't happen until I was in my 30s.
Not going to college.

I wish I had never started drinking alcohol. I'm a full blown alcoholic at 57 years old and am deciding whether or not to drink myself to death because I feel so trapped with the AA meetings closed down.

Letting myself drift into things like where to go to college, my first job, my career, life partner. I have not actively managed my life. I have great potential and if actively managed I think I could have been great.

I blindly followed my parents wishes instead of my own desires for an education early in life and was afraid to make family unhappy with me. 
I did not speak my heart in many situations and lost the opportunity later in losing either a work or personal relationship.

I regret not taking advantage of spending time with my grandparents as a child. I resented their presence in my home and their desire to connect with me, and now I'd do anything to get that time back.

wasting so much time
sometimes not being brave enough when it comes to changes in bad situations and having it in my own hands

i regret to not travel more before my ms got a more severe shape. now my disability restricts me to very organized and not so free traveling. and everything is expensive now. just go to an unorganized beach and spend an afternoon in a hammock is undoable now, i'd need a paved way and a beach wheelchair or whatever and some people are busy helping just me. that just sucks. i regret not to visit more places, i was working all the time. damn stupid. now i have money but also i have a thousand undoable things.

(1) Not travelling to Poland to meet the Dad of my wife before he died. (Actually he just died this Monday)
(2) Not staying in the USA and bring the love of my life to the USA. Instead I returned to Europe. Never know how that would have turned out.

I felt that I need a new challenge in my professional career. In 2018 work sucked and I was feeling really depressed, however I did not dare to change job. My loan on the house, 2 kids and wife kept me from changing something. But things got even worse, I stayed on the job and 2019 became a complete desaster. I regret that I did not have the courage to change company in 2018 and then finally got pushed out in 2019.

Not having developed the self-confidence to join groups where I could have met more people interested in some of the same hobbies and activities that I enjoy.  This would have led to more friendships, something I sorely missed having this year during the pandemic.

Putting so much pressure on college instead of experience in the field.
I regret not taking better care of myself emotionally. I should have ended a relationship sooner.

Not setting boundaries earlier in life which meant working too much and not being clear on what I wanted in relationships. I listen to my body now if I should or shouldn’t be doing something, whether it’s work or personal, and it’s made such a difference.

Not being more confident in my abilities, when interacting with others. Being less present in the moment, was the reason. That made my interpersonal interactions dull and affected by ability to influence others. Also, that made me fickle and affected by resilience at work. Although, I am fortunate that things turned out good, but I could have aimed much higher. I will display more confidence in 2021.

not prioritizing my mental health sooner

Comparison is the thief of happiness, and my pursuit of accomplishments took precedence over building relationships. Judge your life by your friendships and lives you have truly touched, not material status and possessions.

During my college days, I ultimately limited my friends group to a small group of folks in the LBGTQ community. Due to the lack of acceptance of that lifestyle at the time, we shut ourselves off from broader activities and opportunities presented by the university. We also frequently smoked pot and and drank alcohol. I briefly smoked cigarettes. While I gained a lot of self-awareness and understanding of the world, I did lose "myself" for a while as I conformed to the group's expectations. Looking back, I missed out on a lot of what the college experience had to offer and missed out on many opportunities to grow, learn and spread my wings, developing my individual skills and talents. I have no regrets now about where I have arrived today, and certainly my experiences then have led me here. But...
I regret not dealing with my drinking earlier

Not going to graduate school at Penn State back in 1969. 
Stop drinking when I was 25 years old.
unwise when choosing life partner
Living in a different part of the country
Getting married soon after college, selling myself short.
Drinking too much in high school and undergraduate
I wish I would have married out of love instead of thinking I could be a rescuer  to my ex-wife.

I’m 56 as of 12-20-20. At 46, I became the target of a workplace bully. In that phase I read “A whole New Mind”. I followed the link for the empathy test and scoring 21 first time and 19 the second time. I discovered I was on the Autism Spectrum and that changed me, my relationships, everything improved. Turns out, it was the “Beam in my eye”.

I regret I didn’t learn that when I was a child like they do today.
Not divorcing a mentally cruel spouse
Not finishing my masters degree program.
Not pursuing a career earlier in life
1. I made choices at an early age about who I was going to be. I resent the fact that I felt I had to force myself to fit an archetype, and I resent who I chose to be.

I regret not realizing I have choice and other people’s happiness or survival isn’t my responsibility. I spent a lot of time in my 20’s & 30’s being concerned with everyone else and not as much with myself. Just because someone wants to date / marry me doesn’t mean I have to agree.
I can’t think of any significant regrets. I’ve had a wonderful life.

I regret listening to my mother and not following my heart's desire to become a teacher. She told me she would not pay for her child to go to college to become a teacher. I floundered for many years and finally became a preschool teacher at the age of 54. I couldn't be happier now, but I was so unproductive and dissatisfied with my career for 30 years.
I regret listening to a therapist about my son’s gender fluid play and my lack of early support and understanding about it.

1.)I would be less afraid. my life is turning out just fine. I worried about so many things and 99% of them did not happen.

2.)I wish I could have lived by A Course in Miracles earlier in my life. It's still a daily (or each minute) struggle. The goal is to listen to the holy spirit and not your ego.
Never studying abroad during college. It would have been an opportunity to actually live in another country and learn the language better!

When I was 19 I left college and was about to move to Austin TX to play music but instead moved to Carmel, NY. Everything that has happened since revolved around that random and sudden decision. I don't regret it so much as wonder what would have happened if we had gone the other route. My life might have turned out completely differently.
I regret being a meanie in 6th grade. I called a girl fat and hid from younger children I was supposed to be walking to school.
Not working harder in high school

Being afraid of change. Fear of the unknown has weighed in too heavily on many of my life's decisions. I have rationalized decisions I have made, when really the reason for not traveling more, changing careers, moving houses....is fear of change.
Not getting my degree sooner, or before age 25.
My one regret is not living closer to extended family and my parents.  As a young married couple, I didn't appreciate that place is about the people around you.  Home is where the heart is idea.
I regret being afraid and ashamed of the disorganization of my finances. I let them get out of control for no reason and Hid from something easily Avoided.

I regret not being nicer to my mom. I took her for granted when I was younger, thinking that I was so much smarter than she was (typical teenager). When I grew up, we argued over politics, both of us passionate about our viewpoints. Now she is gone, and I miss her desperately, so much that it takes my breath away sometimes. I did the daughter thing all wrong. I look at my daughters and pray that they are kinder to me than I as to my own mom, even though I'm not sure I deserve it.
I regret that I didn't build the habit of saving money.
I regret not looking at the positive side of life more. It is so easy to focus on negative elements in the moment.

I am a first-generation Asian American. My HS and college years took place during the 90s and without having outside guidance, I regret allowing my family and Asian culture to influence my career pursuits. I pivoted from things I was truly passionate about and were considered riskier - film/tv, music - to things that were within reach and secure - technology, software development. I look back and am grateful for the life I have and where I am, but believe I could have found security and be working on things I truly love versus things I know I can do.
I should have worked while going to college, instead of relying on student loans. Now I am suffering considerable debt.

I wish I had listened to my own voice and made my personal decisions instead of my mother. Being an indian woman, we have  a lot of cultural & society pressure. But I am much happier marrying a person my choice.
Not living below my means, from my first job onward and not realizing that people, relationships, and experiences were more important than things & status.
not learning to play sports as a kid. therefore lacking social skills & neuro-muscular coordination
I never tried understanding my father.
I regret not to experience enough of my love life in school and college.
I wish I had pursued my dream of studying at NYU.
I regret being very impulsive. Though I have no control over it. I won't change too yet the regret would stay.

Albus Dumbledore in Harry Potter once noted "Words are, in my not so humble opinion, our most inexhaustible source of magic, capable of both inflicting injury and remedying it.". I created pain to others which I should not have done. With some patience and maybe an over night sleep, I would have been in a better shape to handle many situations in my life.
Not doing more clinical/research work and not creating contacts with my professors when I had the chance.
Not losing enough weight
Not having been more social in high school

Years ago in the window of an art gallery I saw a pair of ceramic candlesticks with three ducks heads sticking out of the top of each. They made me laugh and made me happy. But they were $75, and I didn't want to spend that money on something so frivolous. The regret continues to this day -- but I have never again refused to spend money on something that makes me (or those I love) happy.
Not applying for universities in California.

My regret is not dreaming bigger and being bolder when I was in my late teens and 20's. The norms for women in the mid '70s to '80s were still a bit traditional. Thank goodness in my 30s I connected with a wonderful and wise mentor who helped me develop into the person I was meant to be, and I'm still developing personally and professionally even in my 60s. I try to pay it forward to those around me whenever the opportunity arises.

I regret pawning my flute. I loved my flute in high school but when I got to college and was broke I pawned it for $30 and never had the money to go back and get it. My mother worked so hard to pay for that instrument when I was in beginner band and I loved it so much. It was my prized possession. I know it sounds silly because it’s a “thing,” but it represented so much more - My mother supporting me and making payments on an instrument we couldn’t afford, hours an hours of practice learning to play, happy memories with my closest friends in marching band. Losing it is something I can’t change and I have a recurring dream about it.
Getting involved in on line intimate relationships.  It damaged the trust in my real relationship.  We recovered but I still feel guilt and shame from it.
Growing up too fast
Moving away from family and the area we have roots, and my family moving away, too.
Marring early
Committing adultery
Having an affair.
From youth sports through college, I was too nervous/shy to go out for certain things. This ranged from being asked to play QB in youth football to not going out for leadership positions in college.
Following society norms and my family's views vs. thinking things through myself.
I didn't become a doctor because I let my mother's thoughts of what I should do prevent me from going to college.
I regret not having children. I decided I wanted to late in life and it may not be possible now.
Not taking more chances - studying abroad in college, moving away after college, etc
I regret not taking time to reach out to people who mean or have meant a lot to me in my life. I regret not being more bold & courageous in "putting myself out there".

Not attending airborne school when suggested to me as an Army ROTC cadet in college. It would have been a unique and significant challenge to undertake, but various fear (failure, looking stupid, not being as good as others) got the better of me.
I regret not getting time off from work in order to attend my sister-in-law’s wedding and my friend’s funeral. I placed work above both of these events.

I wish I'd sought help sooner for post-partum depression after the birth of my daughter. I didn't feel well, struggled to breast feed, felt an absence of joy, and was ashamed of my detached feelings towards her. Sadly I lost two years of both my life and hers.
Sometimes over react
Working instead of spending time with family
Listen to the lies I tell myself.

I wish I had started play competitive basketball earlier in life. I decided to go out for my high school basketball team as a senior after never having done anything put play pick-up games. I made the team and was pretty good. I think if I started seriously earlier in life and had coaching I could have been very good.
I didn't believe in myself.

I regret my college major. Instead of majoring in communications, I majored in education.  Career worked out, but I always wondered “what if”.

I regret that I was not more intentional about assessing my interests and aptitudes and applying them to thinking more strategically about the studies I might pursue in college, for my bachelor's degree. I look back now, at age 56, and realize that I really had no clue at age 18, about what my strengths and talents were and how I might leverage them in my studies and/or future career. I'm quite lucky to have ended up in a career that I've enjoyed and where I've been successful, but it's never been my passion ... and I still don't know where my passion lies. I wish I'd had the insight and courage as a young woman to up-end my very practical upbringing in order to discover and pursue my passion.
I regret leaving the news media - even though it led me to a quality of life I love. But I left a career I had found joy and meaning in, and I have not found that professionally since then.
I regret not having taken time off between college and law school to mature psychologically and emotionally.
I regret not leaving a relationship sooner.
Putting my husband's name on my house.  Lost it in the divorce.

As a child all of the way through early adulthood I regret wanting to fit in so much I adapted who I was and my actions to match those around me. I allowed my lack of confidence to rob myself and those around the chance to know the real me.

As the oldest sibling I felt responsible for the well-being of my brothers. My bossiness pushed them away. I regret not showing more love and understanding.

I regret not pursuing the woman who showed great love for me and who I felt would be a great wife because I didn't feel I measured up to her abilities and commitment. She had so many wonderful attributes and was so right but I didn't see it at the time and that was a huge mistake. I married another woman and was deeply disappointed and eventually divorced her. I was admitted to a PhD program few years ago and chose a charismatic and well known professor to be my supervisor. From the very beginning of our collaboration, she was continuously giving me critical feedback and my work was never good enough for her. I thought the problem was in me. So I worked harder, kept trying, but I kept receiving critical feedback, and in many instances I felt disrespected. One day I decided that's enough, I decided that I was not going to waste any more years trying to change the perception of someone who obviously did not believe in me. I picked another professor to work with and since then my experience has been much better. I still receive critical feedback on my work, but the critical feedback that I am receiving now is helping me improve my work and improve my competences. I regret having spent so many years working under the supervision of someone who did not believe in me and who did not see me as capable
Choosing the wrong mentor
I regret not playing soccer as a youth.

I regret not spending more time nurturing and maintaining friendships and developing more in person long-term relationships. Now I am 54 in a pandemic living alone and dealing with the realization of how short life is.
Regret being absent and alone when family, friends and colleagues needed my presence. Still work-in-progress.

I took an interest survey when I was 23 and it indicated that I was interested in and had a personality conducive to the work of an archeologist. At the time I didn’t see a financially viable future there so I went with studying psychology.....should have chosen archeologist.
I wish I had thanked Steve Beeley before he died. He was pivotal in my having a great career.

I wish I would have said yes more often to my mom when she asked for a favor. She asked me to take her to a memorial service and I was feeling overwhelmed with two small children and a busy career I felt I could not emotionally handle it. But, my Mom didn't ask for much and I wish I would have just said yes more often.

At 57, I recognize I should have taken better care of my health to include diet, exercise when I was younger.  A weekly health routine would have extended my life and I would have had a less steep climb at 57.  Health as we age becomes primary and without your health all of what you worked for to get here can be diminished.

Not trusting my own initial reactions or visceral responses more often. That first blink is usually pretty accurate.
I regret choosing to stay with an emotionally abusive man just because I’d made a vow.
Poor financial decisions such as taking out student loans to fund my education are one of my biggest regrets. I did not seriously look for other ways to pay for my undergraduate and graduate degrees.

I regret not spending more time with my parents. They've both passed away. I can't count the number of times I've said, "I wish mom was here to show me XX or help me with XX" or "I wish dad was here to explain how I'm related to XX or advise me about XX." Not only do I wish I'd spent more time with them, but I also wish I would have filmed them answering questions about our family.

A couple was in the process of adopting two boys from another country asked what they might expect, given that the babies had been abandoned, were infants, and early care was unknown, I responded too curtly.  I said that the children may well have learning and behavior problems.  Who can predict the future?
Going into education as a career. I was a first generation college student and there were teachers in my family so I did what I had been exposed to.
I regret putting so much emphasis on my career when my kids were young. Spending extra time working to advance my salary instead of spending that time with them when they were young.
The one thing that I regret is that I followed the interests of others instead of my own passions. It has had a lasting effect which I continue to struggle with.
Those times I couldn't find a positive in a tough situation. I made too many "surface" decisions.

I am 35 years old. Just recently learnt about financial independence, healthy eating, mindfulness and meditation. It has had a tremendous effect on my life in such a short span of time. Now, my regret is that I didn’t learn about these things in my 20’s. I wonder how different my life would have turned out if I did learn about these things early in my life.
I don’t have any regrets. Good things have came out of all my bad decisions.
Being passive in my decisions, letting others lead that process

no haber dicho te quiero a mas personas, no haber compartido mas tiempo con mi familia.

El se murió con 90 años cuando yo tenía 24... y con el tiempo me di cuenta que tenía que haberle acompañado en sus últimos años como el hizo conmigo en mis primeros años... no lo hice por que no fui consciente...

Tambien me hubiera gustado aprovechar más la época de los 15 a los 30 años... me divertí mucho... y podía además de divertirme haber aprovechado más para aprender y tener experiencias, viajes, etc...

I should have devoted more time to spending time with friends.

I let relationships define me as a young person.  I didn’t figure out or care about what I wanted, I just wanted to keep the other person happy.

A regret that still plagues me is my decision to live safely, follow a boyfriend, and go to a commuter college.  I missed the experience of taking risks, learning more about myself and making friends for life.

In the grand scheme of my life I have no regrets. Had I done anything differently I would have gone off the path that was meant just for me and I wouldn’t be in the exact spot I am today. Excepting the good and the bad is all part of self actualization. We need the Ying and yang.

regretList.regret: I don't regret anything. I don't agree with the statement: I wish I had done something differently. Because I can't do it differently now! I look forward and see what I can do next. There is no point to looking back. It is all about how you navigate your way around a challenge. If you feel you lost an opportunity, what are you going to do about it? What's your next step? I wanted to travel round the world with a friend when I was in my 20s. It never happened and never will because she died suddenly. Do I regret that I never did that trip with her? No. But I do look forward to the day I can travel the world again and I will always cherish the memory of my friend.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I regret allowing myself to stay in a bad situation at work for too long just because I thought it was a good opportunity to be in the position and that nothing else mattered. It took me a couple of years after having the mental breakdown which lead to me quitting the position, to gain the clarity to see that I was being bullied and that I did have more power than I realised at the time to put a stop to it in other ways without having to reach my personal limit.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Ikigai is a Japanese word that roughly translates to “a reason to get out of bed in the morning". I'm 48 and have never really found my Ikigai. A key moment was choosing the wrong course at university and then sticking with it. I was young, had no real life experience and made choices with input from other people who didn't have good insight. I never knew it was possible to study something you might actually want to do! I never took time to figure out what I was good at enjoyed doing. And after university the ripples of that choice continued. I then stayed in a role I found incredibly stressful (but was very good at) for over 15 years until I had a breakdown !! Finally in my 40's I am doing a job I really enjoy but if I'm being honest with myself, even that is founded on making the wrong choice at university and not taking the time to find nor to follow my true purpose.  I wish I had explored more, taken more risks and learned more about myself so I could feel truly fulfilled at work.

regretList.regret: I regret not being true to myself with my first love.  I did not have the confidence to tell her exactly how i felt and it troubled me for a long time and impacted many decisions that led me to some dark places.

regretList.regret: I regret the time I have wasted. I wish I had had more confidence and self belief in my youth. I regret being so governed by my parents' and my husband's expectations of me and not realising my life was mine until into my 40's.

regretList.regret:
I would love to travel back to Jan 2018. My biggest regret is not realising a dear friend was on the brink of suicide. I knew he was unhappy and we talked openly about the high levels of stress he was experiencing at work. He was due to retire in a matter of months, but had one final all-encompassing project to finish.

I'd known Ryo ever since I was a child. He was a family friend and was always one of my favourite people. I'll never forget that last conversation I had with him. We sat on the sofa and sang Leonard Cohen songs – he knew all the lyrics. Looking back on our conversation there were so many clues that he was suicidal but I didn't know what to look for at the time. He took his life a month later.

There needs to be greater societal awareness of suicide. If only we all knew the signs to look out for, so many needless deaths could be prevented. I hope we can live in a more open, stigma-free, compassionate world. Open, honest conversation is the key to living well.

I lost sight of what meant so much to me and became so confident that she would still be fine for a couple more years. When I decided to leave Canada in 2010 to go back home to Manila - my reason was that my Mom was getting older and I wanted to be there for her and my siblings. She wasn't sick and she was still well ... for me it was payback time. She and my Dad (who passed 2001) were the best parents -- very selfless; never asked for anything; brought us up with values and principles I am very proud of.  I was there ... then I left ... then she was gone.

It was ugly and not how I wanted to present myself or the organization. I left the meeting feeling terrible. Soon after, she gave me a horrible performance review, re-organized the department, fired a beloved colleague, and I rejected the "new" position they offered me and quit. It was all a terrible experience, but the thing I regret the most is NOT taking the high road in that meeting, for not having the savvy to know she had already been tasked with making significant changes.
